Kotlin Code Smells 10— Null













Yonatan Karp-Rudin



·Follow




Published inStackademic



·

2 min read·
Dec 16, 2022








--










Listen









Share












TL;DR: Null does not exist in the real world. Its creator regrets it, and
programmers worldwide suffer from it. Avoid being a part of it.Programmers often use null to represent various conditions such as absence, undefined values, or errors. However, this leads to coupling and errors due to multiple interpretations.
Problems
Coupling between callers and senders.
Mismatch between callers and senders.
Pollution with if/when statements.
Null is not polymorphic with real objects, resulting in Null Pointer Exceptions.
Null does not exist in the real world, violating the Bijection Principle.
Solutions
Avoid using nullable types whenever possible.
Use the NullObject pattern to eliminate conditional statements.
Exceptions
APIs, databases, and external systems where null does exist.
Sample Code
Wrong


Right


Conclusion
null is often considered a billion-dollar mistake. Despite that, many programming languages support its usage, and libraries even encourage it. In Kotlin, it's recommended to avoid nullable types unless absolutely necessary, and if needed, utilize the NullObject pattern to represent the absence of a field.

</figure><pre class="no np nq nr ns nt nu nv bo nw ba bj"><span id="775a" class="nx ny gr nu b bf nz oa l jf ob"><strong class="nu gs">TL;DR:</strong> Null does not exist in the real world. Its creator regrets it, and<br>
programmers worldwide suffer from it. Avoid being a part of it.</span></pre><p id="bfe3" class="pw-post-body-paragraph oc od gr oe b of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq or os ot ou ov ow ox oy oz gk bj">Programmers often use <code class="cw pa pb pc nu b">null</code> to represent various conditions such as absence, undefined values, or errors. However, this leads to coupling and errors due to multiple interpretations.</p>
<h1 id="6d43" class="pd ny gr be pe pf pg ph pi pj pk pl pm pn po pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw px py pz bj">Problems</h1>
<ul class=""><li id="c916" class="oc od gr oe b of qa oh oi oj qb ol om on qc op oq or qd ot ou ov qe ox oy oz qf qg qh bj">Coupling between callers and senders.</li>
<li id="0137" class="oc od gr oe b of qi oh oi oj qj ol om on qk op oq or ql ot ou ov qm ox oy oz qf qg qh bj">Mismatch between callers and senders.</li>
<li id="61a7" class="oc od gr oe b of qi oh oi oj qj ol om on qk op oq or ql ot ou ov qm ox oy oz qf qg qh bj">Pollution with <code class="cw pa pb pc nu b">if</code>/<code class="cw pa pb pc nu b">when</code> statements.</li>
<li id="b634" class="oc od gr oe b of qi oh oi oj qj ol om on qk op oq or ql ot ou ov qm ox oy oz qf qg qh bj">Null is not polymorphic with real objects, resulting in Null Pointer Exceptions.</li>
<li id="1117" class="oc od gr oe b of qi oh oi oj qj ol om on qk op oq or ql ot ou ov qm ox oy oz qf qg qh bj">Null does not exist in the real world, violating the <a class="af qn" href="https://maximilianocontieri.com/the-one-and-only-software-design-principle" rel="noopener ugc nofollow" target="_blank">Bijection Principle</a>.</li>
</ul><h1 id="7bc5" class="pd ny gr be pe pf pg ph pi pj pk pl pm pn po pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw px py pz bj">Solutions</h1>
<ul class=""><li id="0efe" class="oc od gr oe b of qa oh oi oj qb ol om on qc op oq or qd ot ou ov qe ox oy oz qf qg qh bj">Avoid using nullable types whenever possible.</li>
<li id="1858" class="oc od gr oe b of qi oh oi oj qj ol om on qk op oq or ql ot ou ov qm ox oy oz qf qg qh bj">Use the <a class="af qn" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Null_object_pattern" rel="noopener ugc nofollow" target="_blank">NullObject pattern</a> to eliminate conditional statements.</li>
</ul><h1 id="94c4" class="pd ny gr be pe pf pg ph pi pj pk pl pm pn po pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw px py pz bj">Exceptions</h1>
<ul class=""><li id="ae66" class="oc od gr oe b of qa oh oi oj qb ol om on qc op oq or qd ot ou ov qe ox oy oz qf qg qh bj">APIs, databases, and external systems where <code class="cw pa pb pc nu b">null</code> does exist.</li>
</ul><h1 id="11e7" class="pd ny gr be pe pf pg ph pi pj pk pl pm pn po pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw px py pz bj">Sample Code</h1>
<h2 id="9928" class="qo ny gr be pe qp qq dx pi qr qs dz pm on qt qu qv or qw qx qy ov qz ra rb rc bj">Wrong</h2>
<figure class="no np nq nr ns ni"><div class="rd jh l fg"><div class="re rf l"></div>
</div>
</figure><h2 id="e8f8" class="qo ny gr be pe qp qq dx pi qr qs dz pm on qt qu qv or qw qx qy ov qz ra rb rc bj">Right</h2>
<figure class="no np nq nr ns ni"><div class="rd jh l fg"><div class="re rf l"></div>
</div>
</figure><h1 id="45d4" class="pd ny gr be pe pf pg ph pi pj pk pl pm pn po pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw px py pz bj">Conclusion</h1>
<ul class=""><li id="3b8f" class="oc od gr oe b of qa oh oi oj qb ol om on qc op oq or qd ot ou ov qe ox oy oz qf qg qh bj"><code class="cw pa pb pc nu b">null</code> is often considered a billion-dollar mistake. Despite that, many programming languages support its usage, and libraries even encourage it. In Kotlin, it's recommended to avoid nullable types unless absolutely necessary, and if needed, utilize the NullObject pattern to represent the absence of a field.</li>
</ul></div>
</div>
</div>
